intro: Clibadium lehmannianum, commonly known as the African devil's backbone, is a climbing plant native to tropical Africa. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its slender, twining stems and opposite, ovate leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers that are clustered in racemes, followed by distinctive, spiny capsules that contain numerous seeds. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and horticulturists alike.
